article.description:
Kansas administered its annual 
beating of an in-state Division II rival.
article.headline: Jayhawks tear into Emporia State
article.linkText: Kansas administers annual beating of D-II team
article.story: LAWRENCE, Kan. (AP) -- Kirk Hinrich drained a 3-pointer and sprinted back down the court, his usual intense look replaced by a wide grin. And why shouldn't he smile? His back felt good, his shot was falling and basketball was fun again. "I haven't been having enough fun lately,'' said Hinrich, who matched his career high with five 3-pointers and scored 23 points as Kansas (No. 19 ESPN/USA Today, No. 20 AP) beat Emporia State 113-61 on Saturday night. "I've been playing with a lot of intensity but not enough enthusiasm. I just decided to kick back, play my butt off and have some fun.'' Wayne Simien also had 23 points -- a career high -- for Kansas (5-3), which reached the 100-point mark before the midpoint of the second half of its annual matchup against an in-state NCAA Division II team. Nick Collison added 19 points, Keith Langford finished with 13 points and Aaron Miles had 13 assists for the Jayhawks, who led the Hornets (4-4) 34-10 after 8½ minutes and 64-23 at the half. That 41-point halftime lead was Kansas' largest since Jan. 14, 1993, when the Jayhawks led Oral Roberts by 46 points (75-29) at intermission. "We were just happy to be in Allen Fieldhouse instead of trying to win,'' Emporia State Coach David Moe said. "That's why they just whipped us.'' Emporia State didn't reach double figures until Shawn Herrman's tip-in with just over 12 minutes left in the half. By that time, Collison already had 10 points -- including 2-for-2 shooting from long range -- and the Jayhawks led 30-10. "That's a shot I'm going to take when the time's right,'' said the 6-foot-10 Collison, who normally plays physical ball inside for the Jayhawks. "If it's in a situation where we're not getting a lot of good shots off, I won't take it.'' Collison also had two 3-pointers in Kansas' 89-80 win over No. 17 Tulsa on Wednesday night, but coach Roy Williams said he's not looking to the big forward to provide outside shooting on a regular basis. "Somebody asked me today if he had the green light to shoot the 3, and I said no,'' Williams said. "But if he's going to go 2-for-3 every time out, I guess I'll let him shoot it.'' The Hornets hit three quick 3-pointers in an 11-3 run that cut the margin to 37-21, but Kansas answered with a 29-2 run -- including one unbroken string of 19 points -- and never again led by fewer than 41 points. "We know they're not like a Top 25 team, but we also know that we are not out there to practice,'' Collison said. "Every time we step out on the court to play, we know we need to play as well as we can and get the job done.'' Simien scored eight points in a 10-0 run that gave Kansas its first 50-point lead, 81-30, on his dunk with 15:02 left. Two free throws by Langford with 11:38 remaining made it a 60-point game, 96-36, and Simien's basket on an inbounds play with 10:03 left put the Jayhawks up 100-45. Williams pulled his starters for good a minute after that. Emporia State finished with 23 turnovers, which the Jayhawks converted into 38 points. The Jayhawks shot 62 percent (43-for-69) from the field while holding the Hornets to 34 percent (21-for-62). Robbie Ballard hit four 3-pointers and led Emporia State with 14 points. Brady Webb added 12 points, and Thomas Vincent had 10 points. The Hornets were 12-for-38 from 3-point range. "We shot a lot more 3-pointers than normal,'' Ballard said. "They're so tough on defense that we just settled for shooting the three.''
